Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Laplace equation \( \Delta u = 0 \) in a region \( \Omega \). An external boundary condition is applied as \( u = 0 \) on \( \partial \Omega \). We investigate the response of the system when subjected to an internal potential \( f(z) = \sin(kz) \), where \( z \) and \( k \) are complex numbers.

If at a certain point \( z_1 \), a new internal potential \( g(z) = \cos(kz) \) is introduced as an intervention, will the final form of \( u(z) \) in \( \Omega \) depend only on the Laplacian \( \Delta \) and not on \( f(z) \) or \( g(z) \)?
Explanation: The intervention of an additional internal potential \( g(z) \) affects the distribution of \( u(z) \) throughout \( \Omega \). The harmonic property of \( u(z) \) influenced by different internal conditions \( f(z) \) and \( g(z) \) matters, establishing dependency beyond just the Laplacian operator.
